The software update Microsoft released to address this vulnerability enforces the use of BR/EDR Secure Connections defined encryption and authentication algorithms for Bluetooth pairings that have used BR/EDR Secure Connections. For more information see the Executive Summary section. This is an informational change only. 
Mitre: CVE-2023-24023 Bluetooth Vulnerability 
On this page 
 
CVE-2023-24023 
Security Vulnerability 
Released: Nov 14, 2023 Last updated: Jan 18, 2024 
Assigning CNA: 
Mitre 
CVE-2023-24023  
 
Impact: Spoofing 
Max Severity: Important 
Microsoft is aware of the Bluetooth Forward and Future Secrecy Attacks and Defenses (BLUFFS) vulnerability. For more information regarding the vulnerability, please see  
this statement 
 from the Bluetooth SIG. 
To address the vulnerability, Microsoft has released a software update that enforces the use of BR/EDR Secure Connections defined encryption and authentication algorithms for Bluetooth pairings that have used BR/EDR Secure Connections. If a paired device used BR/EDR Secure Connection at some point, Windows will enforce all subsequent BR/EDR connections to use BR/EDR Secure Connections. 
As defined by the BR/EDR Secure Connections protocol, the new BR/EDR Secure Connections algorithms will only be used when the local system and the remote paired device both support BR/EDR Secure Connections. Connections between the local system and the remote paired device will remain vulnerable if either the local system or the remote paired device never declare support for BR/EDR Secure Connections during encryption or authentication.. 
Additionally, it is advised to increase the minimum encryption key size as described in  
Windows guidance for Bluetooth key length enforcement 
. Increasing the minimum encryption key size does not require support for BR/EDR Secure Connections.

metadata.summary: Microsoft has addressed the CVE-2023-24023 Bluetooth vulnerability, impacting Windows 10, 11, and Server 2019/2022. The vulnerability allows spoofing attacks and is related to the use of BR/EDR Secure Connections. Microsoft released a software update enforcing the use of specific encryption and authentication algorithms for Bluetooth pairings that have used BR/EDR Secure Connections. This update aims to mitigate the vulnerability by ensuring the use of secure connections for subsequent Bluetooth pairings. It is crucial to note that the new BR/EDR Secure Connections algorithms will only be utilized if both the local system and the remote paired device support BR/EDR Secure Connections. Additionally, increasing the minimum encryption key size, as per Windows guidance, is advised to enhance security. The exploitability assessment indicates that the vulnerability is less likely to be exploited. System administrators are urged to apply the security updates for the affected Windows versions to safeguard against potential spoofing attacks. For more information, refer to the Microsoft Security Updates page.
metadata.nvd_description: bluetooth br/edr devices with secure simple pairing and secure connections pairing in bluetooth core specification 4.2 through 5.4 allow certain man-in-the-middle attacks that force a short key length, and might lead to discovery of the encryption key and live injection, aka bluffs.
